--in this POST-Brexit period. The ultimate decision will have far reaching impact on who will be able to identify as ‚ÄúIrish Citizens‚Äù in the North of Ireland moving forward. 

I stand with Emma and her husband in her demand to be recognized as an Irish citizen.

However, the UK Home Office rejected her application on the grounds that it considered her to be a British citizen because she was born in the North of Ireland. Her case, now in it‚Äôs 5th year, would be the first human rights challenge to the Good Friday Agreement --

Ms. DeSouza is from County Derry. In 2015, she applied for a residence card to permit her US-born husband Jake (originally from Philadelphia) to live and work in the North of Ireland. On her application, she identified herself as an Irish citizen.

Her case concerns Article 1 of the #GoodFridayAgreement which recognizes the right of people born in Northern Ireland to identify as either British, Irish, or both, and accordingly to hold both British and Irish citizenship.
